you're trying to make...of which you made none.
comments.author: Al Shurdom

comments.text:
+Joey Joe Joe Bullseye.  Back when the S&Ls were collapsing, I was a 
Libertarian, and it was obvious to me that Reagan had "deregulated" them 
exactly backwards.  Rather than removing all regulations while keeping 
FSLIC guarantees in place as the Republicans did, a Libertarian Congress 
would have made FSLIC membership voluntary, and simply made sure everyone 
knew which institutions were Federally insured and which weren't.
Of course, even with Reagan's guaranteed-crisis setup, the damage could 
have been greatly reduced if the FSLIC had simply carried out its legal 
mandate to repay all lost deposits up to $400k and told the multi-million 
dollar depositors, "Sorry!"
These days, I'm a Warren Democrat, but I'd *still* be willing to make FDIC 
membership voluntary.

comments.author: jd13681

comments.text:
Did you know that the Koch brothers have pledged $880 million dollars 
toward buying the 2016 election? Do you think that should be legal? Do you 
think they won't demand to have legislation in their favor in return?  What 
a sad situation our country is in when this is our electoral process. 

The republicans are now on the income inequality and declining middle class 
bandwagon. But they need to check their historical facts for the reason. 
The best economic period in history was the 1950s and 1960s which the tea 
party says is their goal to return the USA to. The middle class was the 
driving force behind that economy as they were the consuming machine that 
made that such a great time. A family could thrive with the husband working 
a blue collar job while the wife stayed home to raise the children. They 
could afford to buy a home, a car, take a vacation every year and save for 
their kids college and their daughter's wedding as well as retirement.

But how was it possible? Because of socialism. Yes that is factually 
accurate! That was a period with the largest amount of wealth distribution 
in our country's history. The rich were taxed up to 90%  and it was 
redistributed through the GI bill to pay for college and housing and job 
creation. Home prices were regulated, as was health care, the price of 
milk, gasoline, utilities, air travel, automobile prices, and 1 in 3 
workers were in a union. There was one phone company, Ma Bell, that leased 
you your telephone. It was illegal to own a bar of gold and businesses were 
taken to task if they were unethical or did illegal things. 

So when you think of the prosperity of the golden era of America at least 
be honest why it was so successful. ﻿
comments.author: Dinner with Mariah

comments.text: +Dinner with Mariah  Yes these super pacs have to go
comments.author: T Wilson

comments.text:

comments.text: You're depressing me :/
comments.author: jakegibson

comments.text:
+Dinner with Mariah There's one minor detail you've left out as a possible 
cause of the great economic boom of that time period. In the '40's, we kind 
of bombed Japan, made Germany pay reparations for decades, and the rest of 
the developed world was center stage of this whole conflict. If all your 
economic competition is either 1) dying from nuclear radiation, 2) 
completely broke from being held liable for the war or 3) having to rebuild 
vast swaths of the countryside after intense fighting had occurred, then 
yes, I could see how the US would be enjoying relative economic success. 
Don't you think the outcome of WW2 has maybe a smidgen to do with why we 
were so economically powerful in that time?

comments.text:
+Toxically Masculine
I wish more people would realize this about corporations and the 2 party 
system. All the "GOP are for the rich" and "Dems are for the poor" 
foolishness is ignorant. BOTH parties are for the rich. I distrust the 
Republicans a little less because at least they don't wrap themselves in 
some fake self righteous mantle of defending the poor while they support 
their wealthy donors, as the Democratic party does. I am often reminded of 
the "populares" and "optimates" of the Roman Republic. The populares 
claimed to represent the "people." While no doubt, as today, some were 
sincere, in the end they were just as power hungry and self interested as 
their opposition. After all, Julius Caesar, who of course declared himself 
dictator for life, was one.
comments.author: TheTubbsfox

comments.text:
+Dinner with Mariah But your entire historical premise on why the U. S. 
manufacturing economy boomed in the 50's is a fiction. American workers 
didn't do so well in the 50's because there was some magic in the air, much 
less because of socialism. You are putting the cart before the horse. The 
reason they did so well was because so much of the manufacturing capacity 
of the West had been blown all to hell in this little skirmish called WWII. 
The reason the U. S. was doing so well was because we had the only game in 
town. Capital goes where it is treated best, and that was here. The only 
large, stable, functioning manufacturing base left was ours, so we could 
afford to pay our people most - there was no competition, and moving 
overseas at the time was foolish. And our relative economic strength 
declined, not because of the Koch brothers or the evils of capitalism, or 
because we dropped the tax rates from 90%, but because the rest of the 
world developed quickly and was able to compete again. Tax revenues 
actually increased when the rates were dropped from 90%. And not because of 
some trickle down foolishness, but because what rational person is going to 
increase their workload to only get 10% of their pay? If you worked for a 
rate of $100/hour at a tax 35% rate, but when you hit 40 hours a week that 
tax rate went to 90%, would you work extra? For a take home of $10? Hell 
no! 
What did result from that wealthy time was corporate complacency, which has 
hurt us. The reason companies like Toyota and Honda were able to suddenly 
compete with and at times surpass U. S. car companies was because many 
companies here never stopped to notice that the world had changed, and they 
weren't changing with it. Japanese companies developed many new operation 
and management ideas that allowed them to blow past us. Heard of "just in 
time" manufacturing, or "kiazen," or lean manufacturing? Japanese ideas 
after WWII, much of it pioneered at Toyota.  
Finally, did you know that we now manufacture more in the U. S. than we 
ever have before? Despite all the companies going overseas, all the 
supposed tax breaks they get for going, despite the higher wages that our 
workers demand, we make more stuff here than ever. Do you know why that 
hasn't translated into more jobs? Automation. Unless you plan on smashing 
up machines like some neo-Luddite, those jobs are just gone. Machines do 
them better, cheaper, and faster. 
You can't put that egg back together again. Unless you are expecting a 
large portion of the world's manufacturing capacity to be blown to bits, 
and yet again we come out unscathed, it's a pipe dream. The 50's and 60's 
are long gone, and dreamy socialism isn't going to bring it back. 
Read some history, take some business, tax, and econ classes.
comments.author: TheTubbsfox

comments.text:
koch brothers will defend their republican buddies, and tons of other 
billionaires will defend their democrat buddies. our problems will not go 
away until we get rid of citizens united. pretending that we have to push 
back against republicans by voting for democrats is just moronic. the 
biggest donors are always republican, and the most total donations are 
always democrat. that is, the democrats pull in more money, but the 
republicans pull in bigger individual donations from fewer donors. so the 
whole system is corrupt. both parties are corrupt. and frankly, they're 
both on the same team in most ways. they just want to rob us in different 
ways... we will continue to have problems until we realize that it's not 
right vs. left, red vs. blue, or old vs. young, it's rich vs. poor. as soon 
as we take our country back from the banking elite, who pay for BOTH 
PARTIES IN THE SAME ELECTION, we'll be fucked. you heard me right. there 
are tons of corporations and elites that give donations to people who are 
fighting against each other in the same election. they'll donate to a 
democrat and a republican who are both fighting for the same seat. why? so 
that, no matter which one wins, they can call in favors. they'll call and 
say "hey, i gave you $50,000. are you gonna kill this bill for me?" to 50 
or more senators on BOTH sides of the aisle. why do you think this 
particular bill didn't pass? why do you think it was bilaterally defeated? 
both republicans and democrats killed it because the people who were paying 
for their campaigns would have lost a lot of money if it passed. both 
parties get huge money from the banking cartels. it's just a fact. obama 
himself got huge money from the same people. WAY more money than all the 
senators got combined. so when you have republicans and democrats voting 
the same way, not because they both agree a bill is bad, but because 
they're both getting paid by a bill's enemy, we've got serious problems. 
why do they agree the bill is bad? because they're getting paid by the same 
people. campaign contributions are an insurance policy for elites. it costs 
them small money, to save them big money in the long run. the kochs will 
give $880 million to save $5 billion in the long run, and so will the 
people donating to the democrat party. it's all the same. parties mean 
nothing, except on the small issues like religion, same-sex marriage, 
abortion, and gun rights. the leftists will raise taxes... but not on the 
elites! the republicans will lower taxes... but especially for the elites! 
that's how it always goes. it's not because of their ideology. it's because 
they are buddying around with the same people, but they have to pretend to 
be different, otherwise the american public will realize that they're not 
getting any choice in who to vote for. as long as they seem different in 
small ways, the average voter will assume that voting for one party is 
different from voting for another party. that way, they feel like they have 
a choice, and they don't revolt. but do they really have a choice? the only 
thing you can choose for is whether you want gay people to get married, or 
guns to not be confiscated. vote red, and you can have your guns. vote 
blue, and gay people can get married. it's really the only difference. your 
wallet is gonna be in the same condition either way: empty. personally i'm 
not gay, and i think marriage is a really stupid decision for anyone, so 
i'd rather vote republican. i think they're catering to a bunch of 
religious fucktards, but who cares? they're not going to sell out my guns 
to the elites, so that we couldn't even start a revolution if we wanted to. 
and i can't see why anyone would want to get married when divorce is at 
60%, and will cost you your house, car, and money... including gay 
people... so i don't see why it matters to me. i don't feel bad denying 
marriage to other people, even though i feel that they should have equal 
rights. it's like giving gay people the "right" to be robbed blind by a 
bunch of criminals. yes they should have the "right" to be fucked over, but 
who cares? i don't even want the right to get married myself! i'd much 
rather gay people have the right to own a gun than have the right to get 
married, since getting married *sucks*, and owning a gun will save your 
fucking life and possibly this country.

keep it in mind for 2016...
comments.author: Toxically Masculine

comments.text:
+TheTubbsfox I don't hate poor people but at what cost to the US does this 
occur? How many American jobs were lost because corporations wanted more 
profit and shipped jobs to places they didn't have to pay much for labor? I 
certainly do care about the poor....the working poor in this country who 
are full-time employees and not making a living wage, therefore they are at 
risk if they get sick or lose their jobs. 
You want us to pay a living wage to people in the 3rd world countries that 
do our manufacturing now right? Yet the right doesn't think it should be a 
requirement to pay a living wage to American workers. 
Free trade has also take American jobs and destroyed our middle class.

comments.text:
Productive capacity in the developing world in the 50's compared to now was 
virtually nothing. So you want people in developing countries to stay poor? 
Unlike in the 50's in many developing countries, people have jobs 
manufacturing things. In large part because the wages and cost of living 
are lower there. Free trade has benefited us with cheaper products, and 
developing countries with growing wages. Why do you hate poor people?
